Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Tranexamic Acid in Postpartum Haemorrhage

Trial_Design.evidence: In this double-blind, placebo-controlled, randomised trial, women experiencing PPH during Caesarean delivery were randomised to receive placebo (n=57), TXA 0.5 g (n=51), or TXA 1 g (n=53) across eight centres in France from March 2016 to December 2019.

Participants.evidence: women experiencing PPH during Caesarean delivery were randomised

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive placebo (n=57), TXA 0.5 g (n=51), or TXA 1 g (n=53)

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to determine the doseâ€“effect relationship for two regimens of intravenous TXA versus placebo.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the difference in the increase over baseline in plasma D-dimer level 120 min after infusion.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding included patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: randomised to receive placebo (n=57), TXA 0.5 g (n=51), or TXA 1 g (n=53) across eight centres in France from March 2016 to December 2019.

Number_Analysed.evidence: In the placebo group, hyperfibrinolysis was evidenced by a mean increase over baseline of 93% for D-dimer level at 120 min.

Result_Outcome.evidence: A dose of TXA 1 g was associated with smaller increases over baseline (D-dimers: 38%, p=0.003 vs placebo).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were more frequent in the 1 g group but not severe.

Funding.evidence: The study was funded by independent agencies with no influence on the study design or reporting.
